text:
Let's find out
how Andrew Parker plans on
beating his competition.

Andrew: I don't really care
about material things,
money, clothes.

I care about being creative
and pushing myself to the edge.

I'm 23 years old,
and I'm a YouTube escape artist.

A lot of the other performers
are professionals.

I'm just an amateur.
I don't have any fancy props.

I train in the backyard.
Never done it on stage.

It's more of a passion,
not a profession.
My act is super dangerous.

I am completely
submerged underwater.

If I don't get out in time,
I risk drowning.

I would love to show the people
that have supported me,

like my mom and dad,
that practice and dedication

to pull off these stunts --
it is worth it.

I am an amateur performer
tying myself to a weight

and putting myself
in a straitjacket underwater.

That should be
a pretty good indication
of how far I'm willing to go.

This is the biggest stunt
I've ever done.
[ Cheers and applause ]

He's a very
DIY escape artist.

-Oh.
-There he is.

-Hey!
-There he is.
Hello.

Today, I will be put
into this straitjacket,
blindfolded with these goggles.

Rope and duct tape
will be attached to my ankle.

Those will be connected
to these handcuffs...
All right.

...weighed down
by this cinder block.

You did this
in your backyard?

And I'm gonna perform it
in this now.
Oh!

To get out, I'll have to escape
from the straitjacket.

Okay.
And then pick
the handcuffs blind
with nothing but a paper clip.

Okay.
And I will have to do all of
that before I run out of breath.

It's not something I've trained.
I top out about 40, 50 seconds.

[ Laughing ] This is, like,
so ill-prepared.

"I can't hold my breath
that long.

I have asthma.
I gotta use a Q-Tip."

[ Laughing ]
That's perfect.

Clearly,
that is dad over there?

Mom and Dad over there.
Yep.

Jennifer, would you like
to come...?

You know I would love
to help you with this.

All right, now,
you won't be surprised to know
that I have never done this.

You haven't done this?
Wow.

You can do it
as tight as as it goes.

As it will go.
Okey-dokey.

Okay.
Thank you so much.

All right. Just please,
do your -- be --
Do it, do it, do it.

-Good luck, brother.
-Thank you.

Kreischer:
Mom and Dad, are you nervous?

-Little.
-Yeah.

Guys, he's got the paper clip
in his mouth,
goggles on.

-Oh, my God.
-He's going in.

Jennifer: Oh, my gosh.
Oh, my gosh.

The crazy thing with this
is there's no tricks.

What you see
is what you get.

I can't even jump into water
without holding my nose.

Cody:
Getting his breathing down,
getting his heart rate down.
It's a big Houdini move.

Oh, wow. He's already out
of the [bleep] straitjacket.

-Oh, whoa.
-God, this kid's good.
This is lot of energy.

Okay, I don't know
if he's going --

man, I didn't mean, like,
literally the last round.

What does he do
if it's not going right?
Is there a signal?

-Hopefully.
-He's got a hand free.

-Oh, my God.
-Straitjacket's off.

He's still got to pick the lock
to free his ankle.

-He's still blindfolded.
-38 seconds.
He's at his limit breath-wise.
He ain't gonna make it.

He's got this,
he's got this.

He's picking a lock
with a paper clip upside down
and blindfolded.

-Oh! He is not out.
-Oh!

This is longer than he normally
can hold his breath.

[ Clanging ]
Come on, Andrew!
[ Cheers and applause ]
Ooh!
Yeah!

All right.
Didn't make anybody nervous.

-Oh, man.
-God!

-Good job.
-Whoo!
[ Car horns honking ]

-I'm so glad he's alive!
-Me, too!

I was waiting for that leg
to start flailing.

That was amazing.
I got to ask --

How close were you
to running out of breath?

I was right there.
I was out.
Oh, my God.

Rosario, how do you feel
about this act?

I just was freaking out,
and I'm really glad

that you actually did what
you said you were gonna do,

because that doesn't always
happen on this show.

So that was very dangerous.
We're reeling over here.
Cody.

Jennifer put you
in the straitjacket.
First for me, yeah.

Makes it all far more real
for us,

which is what makes this
damn difficult to call.
